results.title: Flame within
results.brief_description: A silent film consisting of a montage of images of family, friends, childhood and home juxtaposed to the words passion, freedom and home - each word with its meaning defined in text.

results.title: TV subtitles
results.brief_description: Angry and frustrated when a hotel did not provide tv’s with tv suibtitles, Robert took matters into his own hands to fight for the rights of people with special needs. With Auslan signing and subtitles.

results.title: I live again
results.brief_description: A moving story of how one man’s life was completely turned inside out when he suffered a stroke resulting in a loss of hearing. With subtitles.

results.title: My journey to strength
results.brief_description: Hilda suffers from deafness and here she gives a frank account of the ups and downs in her life and the traumatic effect of losing her mum just before she turned 18. Through support and determination she has survived years of depression and finally found happiness and acceptance. With subtitles.

results.title: My family
results.brief_description:
After a divorce Nga decides to start life again and migrate to Australia. She reflects on how difficult it is to raise her children alone and how sad she was that she could not afford to give them much and had to work long hours. Nga has come to terms with her guilt and grief when she shares in the successes of her children.
Made at ACMI as part of the ‘Recovering Hope’ Digital Storytelling project, in partnership with VicHealth and Belgium Street Neighbourhood House.

results.title: [Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movies: Reel 10]
results.brief_description:
Tibor Zoltan Koller (1920-1975) was an amateur filmmaker who made home movies in Australia and overseas from the 1940s to the early 1970s. Born in Budapest, Hungary, Tibor lived in Melbourne, Victoria with his family. His wife Merna Koller was a frequent collaborator on these films, showing a shared interest in filmmaking.

Tibor captured suburban family life in Melbourne, including family celebrations, urban scenes and regional holidays. Tibor was actively engaged in the lapidary society of Australia. Several of his films show opal fields and gemstone artisans at work, as well as the 1969 ‘Gemboree’ in Beechworth, Victoria, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. Tibor also travelled to Idar-Oberstein in Germany, historically known as a gemstone town, and to Japan.

The Tibor Zoltan Koller Home Movie Collection has been donated to ACMI by the filmmaker’s daughter Vicki Koller. The films were made on Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

In this film, we see a trip to Beechworth in 1969 for the ‘Gemboree’, a national festival organised by the lapidary clubs of Australia. The first ‘Gemboree’ was held in 1965 as a gathering of lapidaries to showcase gemstones and minerals and has continued annually since. The film opens with elaborate title cards setting up the film, which is credited to both Tibor and wife Merna Koller. The film contains footage of country Victoria and the festival, including great shots of cars, caravans and tents of the era. It also shows interesting footage of gemstones on display.

This film was made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 title card ‘Combined Lapidary Clubs of Victoria presents’, ‘1969 Gemboree Beechworth’
00:00:27:00 ‘Script & Narration: John Royle’
00:00:59:00 ‘Compiled & Filmed by TZ & MM Koller’
00:01:05:00 a man exits a wooden shed in the bush
00:01:48:00 panning for gold in the river
00:02:31:00 signpost ‘Woolshed Falls’
00:03:05:00 children panning for gold
00:04:11:00 sausages cooking on a hot plate
00:04:30:00 ‘Welcome to Beechworth’ road sign, followed by views around the town
00:06:14:00 cars driving down the main street
00:06:24:00 a yellow banner stretched across the road reads ‘Dulux Paints Welcomes You to Gemboree ‘69, National Lapidary Festival’
00:07:44:00 handmade signs for various lapidary clubs and some great examples of caravans and cars of the era
00:09:14:00 crowds of people at the festival
00:12:21:00 1950s style cars
00:13:01:00 a large group of people in the bush prospecting
00:14:09:00 toddler in a play pen
00:14:56:00 a man grinding a gemstone on a grinding wheel
00:15:39:00 ‘Exhibition Entries This Way’ followed by prize winners of the Gemboree on display
00:18:32:00 gemstones on display in cabinets
00:20:18:00 a bonfire

results.title: [Wallace Clarke Home Movies: Reel 32]
results.brief_description:
Wallace Clarke was an amateur filmmaker who was particularly keen on capturing the Australian landscape from the 1960s to the 1990s. As well as Australian urban settings and some world travels, Wallace’s films focus on the many hiking and camping destinations that he visited.

Often carrying the credit, ‘A Walkabout Film’, Wallace’s movies indicate that he was part of a nature study and walking group called ‘The Walkabouters Club of Victoria Inc’. The ‘Walkabouters’ formed in 1968 as a result of a Council of Adult Education (CAE), Outback Study Tour to Central Australia. Some of the attendees decided to start the Club in order to continue educative walks particularly around Victoria. The Club encouraged their resident artists and photographers to capture their activities.

The collection of Wallace’s films was donated to ACMI by his widow Gwenda Clarke and is shot on various formats, predominantly Standard 8mm and Super 8mm film.

This film shows a trip made by the ‘Walkabouters’ to the Wyperfeld National Park in northwestern Victoria. Wallace as usual focuses on the landscape, flora and fauna and in doing so, captures the arid beauty of the region. A highlight of the film is the usually hard to find malleefowl (or hen), an endangered bird in Victoria that Wallace films in its dry, inland scrub habitat. The malleefowl is a mound builder which, unlike any other birds in Australia, uses its large strong feet to create enormous mounds of soil in which their eggs are incubated, heated by the sun or rotting leaves.

Originally made on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:05:00 titles, ‘A Walkabout Film’, ‘Wyperfeld’, ‘Filmed by WHC’
00:00:33:00 a paddock of grazing sheep
00:00:46:00 a sign for ‘Wyperfeld National Park National Parks Service’ and some wildflowers
00:01:27:00 a malleefowl at work on top of its mound, followed by more wildflowers
00:02:08:00 emus
00:02:28:00 chopping fallen logs
00:02:58:00 a brown beetle
00:03:12:00 walkers on a walking track in the Park
00:03:28:00 a bird in a eucalypt (gumtree)
00:04:01:00 sandy terrain and wildflowers
00:05:34:00 a scary looking banksia plant seed pod close-up followed by more examples of banksia pods
00:06:17:00 the ‘Walkerbouters’ itinerary on a black board, including daily destinations and when to carry lunch
00:06:30:00 views of the landscape around the Park and what is likely to be a variety of blue-tongue lizard
00:08:23:00 the walkers’ campsite and another blackboard itinerary notice
00:09:33:00 the walkers rest on a large, fallen tree log
00:11:05:00 birds flying overhead
00:12:38:00 a particularly wide trunk eucalypt (gumtree) tree in the Park attracts the walkers’ attention
00:13:38:00 sandy dune-like mounds throughout the Park
00:14:18:00 walking under what appears to be old tea tree branches and possibly saltbush among more close-ups of wildflowers

results.title: Flash Back: ACMI Collections Mash-up White Night 2017
results.brief_description:
‘Flash Back’, an archival mashup of films and footage from the 1940s through to the ‘80s celebrating the changing face of Australian youth identity and culture.

From rebel youth of the ‘50s, to the ‘70s counter culture revolution and the punk attitudes of the ‘80s, ‘Flash Back’ explores the changing decades through diverse subcultures and the music, fashions and cultural preoccupations that shaped them.

Image: ‘Sharpies: A Gathering’, courtesy Greg Macainsh

Our sincere thanks to filmmakers, musicians and donors for material used in this work. Full details in credits. Edited by ACMI’s Sam Mapplebeck.
